column1: Rockledge  is the oldest city in Brevard County
column2: Florida. The city's population was 24
column3: 926 at the 2010 United States Census
column4: and is part of the Palm Bay−Melbourne−Titusville Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: Rockledge was officially founded on August 7
column3: making it the oldest incorporated municipality in Brevard County. The name Rockledge
column6: comes from the many ledges of coquina rock that line the Indian River. Other sources refer to a man named Cephas Bailey Magruder
column7: who built his home after settling in the area in 1876 near the Indian River. Magruder called his home "the rockledge home" and the name was eventually attributed to the whole town. It was originally referred to as Rock Ledge; the two-word name persisted through the 19th century.

column1: Early industry in the area was based on the citrus trade and accommodation for tourists traveling to South Florida via the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway of the Indian River.President Grover Cleveland and his wife visited the city in 1888.The town had several large hotels in the late 19th century to the early 20th century that catered to Northern tourists escaping cold winters. These included the Hotel Indian River
column2: the Plaza
column3: and the Rockledge Hotel
column4: all located north of Barton Avenue
column5: looking out over the river.Towards the early part of the 20th century
column6: Rockledge was known as a resort town. In the winter months
column7: the population would rise from 200 to almost 2
column9: access to Rockledge was via boat and rail. Steamboats in the Indian River connected with Henry Flagler's trains to bring people to the North. Small boats
column11: and small launches frequently stopped to unload freight and passengers. Most of the tourists in this time were wealthy and would use the boats to connect to the rail system at that time. After World War I
column12: the automobile allowed the average person to travel to the area and their encampments dotted the area. The Dixie Highway was completed in 1915 and spanned most of Florida. In the 1920s
column13: US1 was paved and replaced the Dixie Highway.In 1939–1940
column14: a winter visitor donated the money to construct a hospital. The mayor convinced the council to donate land from the former golf course that had belonged to the defunct Indian River Hotel for the hospital.Rockledge underwent an expansion further west and south in the 1960s when it became a bedroom community for the nearby Kennedy Space Center. Several hundred families from all over the United States settled in the city with the advent of the Apollo missions and the space shuttle program.

column1: Barton Boulevard replaced US 1 as the town's economic center as new subdivisions spread south along Fiske Boulevard. By the 1970s
column2: the bulk of Rockledge's population lived between US 1 and I-95.

column1: Developments stretched north to south from the late 1950s to the 1990s. Virginia Park
column2: Marlin Manor
column3: Fairway Estates
column8: Levitt Park and Woodsmere had all been established by the 1960s-1980s

column1: Levitt Park and Woodsmere were built atop a gladiola farm and an orange grove. The huge Australian Pine trees at the southernmost points of Fiske Boulevard are all that remain of the grove's windbreaks. The subdivision of Silver Pines
column2: while part of unincorporated Brevard County outside the city limit
column3: was also built during this period and is identified by citizens as a part of the city.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 13.4 square miles (34.8 km2)
column3: of which 11.9 square miles (30.9 km2) is land and 1.5 square miles (3.8 km2) (11.03%) is water.It is bounded on the north by Cocoa
column4: on the west by the St. Johns River and scrubland
column5: to the south by Viera (unincorporated) and Melbourne
column6: and to the east by the Indian River Lagoon and Merritt Island (unincorporated) on the opposite shore.

column1: Rockledge has a humid subtropical climate
column2: Köppen climate classification Cfa. The area's warm and humid climate is caused primarily by its proximity to the Gulf Stream
column3: which flows off the east coast of Florida. There are two major seasons which characterize the area. One is hot and rainy
column4: lasting from June until late September. The other is the dry season
column6: brings more moderate temperatures and less frequent rainfall.

column1: Rainfall can run off from the city into the Indian River Lagoon
column2: with resultant pollution. As a result
column3: the city has banned fertilizing from June 1 to September 30 annually.

column1: === Museums and other points of interest ===
Marion S. Whaley Citrus Packing House

The City of Rockledge functions under a Council-Manager government. The Mayor and City Council members are elected to three-year terms. There are six City Council members whose terms are staggered to allow election of two council seats each year. The city holds municipal elections on the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November each year.
While the Mayor and the City Council act as the legislative body of the City of Rockledge
column2: the actual operation of the city and its functions lies with the city manager and his departmental support staff consisting of assistant city manager/finance director
column3: city clerk/public relations officer
column7: director of public works and director of wastewater treatment and water reclamation.

column5: and seven civilian volunteers. All police officers must be certified by the State of Florida. In August 2011

column1: The public schools in Rockledge are operated by the Brevard County Public School Board. Local schools include Hans Christian Andersen Elementary; Golfview Elementary; John F. Kennedy Middle School; Ronald McNair Magnet Middle School; and Rockledge High School.
Private schools include St. Mary's Catholic School
column2: Rockledge Christian School
column3: Trinity Lutheran School
column4: and Rockledge Montessori School. Sawgrass Academy Middle was a former charter school in the town.

column1: Rockledge is served by U.S. Route 1. Major east–west roads are oriented towards this north–south road.
The following are at least four-lane roads
column2: unless otherwise designated.

column1: National roads U.S. 1. – This road was constructed east of the railroad throughout the city. In 2010
column2: it was widened to six lanes throughout Rockledge. A landscaped median was installed. Construction in 2010 cost $27.5 million for 2.6 miles (4.2 km). This section of the road carries approximately 45
column3: 000 vehicles daily. Major intersections include CR 502 and Barton Boulevard.

column1: Interstate 95 – A very small portion runs through the city at Exit 195.State roads SR 519 (Fiske Blvd) is a state road which at the southernmost point connects to Stadium Parkway in Viera and at the northernmost point to SR 520 in Cocoa. SR 519 is a four-lane road.  Major intersections include CR 502
column2: Interstate 95
column3: and Barton Boulevard.County roads CR 502 (Barnes Blvd) links US 1
column5: SR 519 and I-95. CR 502 is a two-lane road except for the easternmost portion which has four lanes that eventually merge into two. Major intersections include Interstate 95

column1: CR 515 (Rockledge Drive) winds along the Indian River edge and is a portion of the Indian River Lagoon Scenic Highway. Along the road are century-old oaks and homes in late 18th century style. There are no major intersections.
Space Coast Area Transit operates a public bus service in Rockledge and vicinity.
The Florida East Coast Railway runs through Rockledge but does not stop. Historically
column2: there was a stop on the Florida East Coast Railway
column3: but it was abandoned when passenger service became unprofitable.

column1: The city has a private runway at the Rockledge Airpark that used to be run by Aero Adventures Inc
column2: but was closed over safety concerns in 2015. The paved runway is approximately 2000 feet with a parallel grass runway on the east side of the property
column3: and a local mechanic operates from the former hangars.
